title: How to Ask Your Partner for More Intimacy

steps.title: Learn a little more about how your partner views your relationship.
steps.content: Learn a little more about how your partner views your relationship. Try to get your partner to dive deep, and talk about things like your morals, your values, and your personalities. You can tell a lot about how your partner thinks about your relationship when they answer this question. Try other ones, like: [1] X Research source “What do you like doing with me?” “What’s something you wish you and I did more of?”

steps.title: Check in about your quality time and your partner’s happiness.
steps.content: Check in about your quality time and your partner’s happiness. If you two don’t live together, they might be missing you throughout the week. Or, your partner might feel like they need a little more alone time, which is a great thing to discuss as a couple. [2] X Expert Source Allison Broennimann, PhD Clinical Psychologist Expert Interview. 11 December 2020. You could also ask questions like: [3] X Research source “Do you like texting throughout the day, or do you prefer talking face to face?” “How much alone time do you think you need?”

steps.title: See what your partner appreciates most about you.
steps.content: See what your partner appreciates most about you. If your partner loves it when you take over a chore for them, they might really appreciate acts of service. If they love it when you give them a hug at the end of a long day, they might really like physical touch. Follow up with other questions like: [4] X Research source “What’s your favorite way to express love?” “What is your love language?”

steps.title: Check in with your partner about what they appreciate.
steps.content: Check in with your partner about what they appreciate. You might talk about how you show love, how you support one another, or how well you two communicate. [5] X Expert Source Allison Broennimann, PhD Clinical Psychologist Expert Interview. 11 December 2020. It’s a good idea to check in about the relationship overall to double check that your partner is happy. [6] X Research source You can also ask things like: “How well do we communicate with each other?” “What’s one thing we could work on in our relationship?”

steps.title: Sexual intimacy is important, too!
steps.content: Sexual intimacy is important, too! If you feel like you and your partner’s sex life has been a little lacking lately, open up the conversation for you to both talk about. [7] X Expert Source Allison Broennimann, PhD Clinical Psychologist Expert Interview. 11 December 2020. You could chat about the frequency, the spontaneity, or even the positions. Then, you can decide if you need to switch it up or change anything. [8] X Research source Follow up with other questions like: “What’s one thing you want to try in the bedroom that we haven’t done yet?” “Do you have any sexual fantasies that you want to share with me?”

steps.title: Have your partner think back to when you two first met.
steps.content: Have your partner think back to when you two first met. This might seem like an out-of-the-box question, but the answer can give you some insight as to how your partner sees you. You can talk about what you thought of your partner and how your impressions of each other have changed over time. [9] X Research source Try asking other questions like: “What did you think of me after our first date?” “How did your impression of me change as you got to know me?”

steps.title: Think back to when you knew your partner was the one.
steps.content: Think back to when you knew your partner was the one. Ask your partner if there’s one single moment they can pinpoint, or if they fell for you gradually over time. This is another fun way to reflect on how far you’ve come in your relationship. Ask other questions too, like: [10] X Research source “Was it love at first sight with me?” “When did you admit to yourself that you might be falling for me?”

steps.title: Give your partner an open platform to divulge any info they want.
steps.content: Give your partner an open platform to divulge any info they want. Sometimes, we keep things from our partner so that we don’t hurt their feelings or burden them. If you think that your partner has been keeping something from you, calmly ask them this question to get a read on what it might be. [11] X Research source You could also ask: “Is there anything that keeps you up at night?” “Are you holding anything back from me right now?”

steps.title: Learn what your partner is afraid of to understand them better.
steps.content: Learn what your partner is afraid of to understand them better. Some people might simply answer with something like “spiders” or “the dark,” but other people might dive a little deeper, with things like “being alone,” or, “living life with regret.” Try to get into these more intimate answers to understand your partner a little better and learn more about what motivates them. You might also ask: [12] X Research source “What were you most afraid of as a kid?” “Are you still scared of the dark?”

steps.title: Sometimes our dream jobs just aren’t realistic.
steps.content: Sometimes our dream jobs just aren’t realistic. You can learn what your partner dreams of doing if they had all the time and money in the world with this simple question! Not only will you learn more about their goals in life, but you might learn what they like to do for fun, too. You could also ask something like: [13] X Research source “What did you want to be when you were growing up?” “Did you always want to be a (current profession)?”

steps.title: Find out what your partner wants to do before they kick the bucket.
steps.content: Find out what your partner wants to do before they kick the bucket. We all have a bucket list in our heads, even if we haven’t written it down on paper. You can ask your partner this question to hopefully help them achieve that goal, whether that’s now or way, way in the future. Try asking other questions too, like: [14] X Research source “What’s something you want to do before you die?” “If today was your last day on earth, what would you do?”

steps.title: Let your partner indulge in their wildest fantasy.
steps.content: Let your partner indulge in their wildest fantasy. See what they would do with an almost unlimited amount of money—they might be practical and say that they’d pay off their debts and buy a house, or they might go crazy and travel the world or go on a shopping spree. It can tell you a lot about how your partner spends their money. You can also ask questions like: [15] X Research source “What would you do if someone handed you $100,000 right now?” “What’s the most amount of money you’d need to live comfortably?”

steps.title: Your partner might tell you a hilarious story you’ve never heard before.
steps.content: Your partner might tell you a hilarious story you’ve never heard before. Or, you might just learn a little bit more about their sense of humor. Figuring out what makes someone laugh is a great way to get them giggling, and it’s something you can use all throughout your relationship. Try asking other questions, like: [16] X Research source “What’s the funniest thing that happened to you this week?” “When’s the last time you laughed so hard that you cried?”

steps.title: Learn more about what makes your partner feel proud.
steps.content: Learn more about what makes your partner feel proud. If they’re really into their career, they might talk about finishing a work project or getting a thumbs up from their boss. If they have a hobby they’re super into, they might talk about learning a new skill or meeting up with other hobbyists. You can also ask things like: [17] X Research source “When was the last time you felt really proud of yourself?” “Do you like it when other people praise you?”

steps.title: Your partner's friends can tell you a lot about them.
steps.content: Your partner's friends can tell you a lot about them. Whatever your partner values in a friendship, they probably value in a relationship, too. Things like loyalty, honesty, and kindness go a long way in a lot of friendships. [18] X Expert Source Allison Broennimann, PhD Clinical Psychologist Expert Interview. 11 December 2020. You can also ask things like: [19] X Research source “What are some friendship deal breakers you have?” “Describe your best friend in 3 words.”

steps.title: Have your partner open up about their emotions with you.
steps.content: Have your partner open up about their emotions with you. Talking about a sad time can be pretty tough, so be prepared to comfort your partner as you two talk. You can also learn how they express their emotions—if the last time they cried in front of someone was a long time ago, they might be a little hesitant to talk about their feelings. Try other questions like: [20] X Research source “How do you cheer yourself up when you’re feeling down?” “Who’s your go-to comfort person?”

steps.title: See how your partner likes to relax with this simple question.
steps.content: See how your partner likes to relax with this simple question. Learning how someone lowers their stress levels is very important in a relationship—there’s a good chance you’re going to have to help them relax at some point. Take note of what they like to do to unwind, and ask them other things, like: [21] X Research source “How do you practice self-care?” “What’s your go-to activity for de-stressing after work?”
